Project   The Small and Medium Enterprise Development Support Project 
Description  (SMEDSP)  is  an  integral  part  of  coordinated  support  of 
development partners to help the Government implement its SME 
Development  Plan  2004–2010.  The  SMEDSP  and  associated 
projects will (i) support policy initiatives to strengthen the enabling 
environment by simplifying registration and licensing processes, 
establish a Philippine business registry, and develop a blueprint 
for a movables collateral registry; (ii) help meet the funding gap for 
SMEs  by  providing  a  credit  line  to  SB  Corporation,  with  a 
Government guarantee, aimed at viable SMEs that currently do 
not have access to bank financing, and a partial credit guarantee 
(PCG)  facility  without  Government  counter  guarantee  to 
encourage selected private sector financial institutions to expand 
their  SME  portfolio,  particularly  to  qualified  medium-size 
enterprises outside the target client group of SB Corporation; (iii) 
strengthen  SB  Corporation’s  credit  underwriting  and  risk 
management;  and  (iv)  help  establish  a  comprehensive  and 
credible credit information system through an equity investment in 
the  planned  credit  information  bureau  (CIB).  The  SMEDSP  is 
processed in parallel with technical assistance (TA) Strengthening 
SME  Credit  Management  Systems  and  a  Japan  Fund  for 
Information  and  Communication  Technology  (JFICT)  project 
Developing  the  Philippine  business  registry,  which  will  support 
items (i) and (iii).  
   
  Rationale  In 2002, SMEs in the Philippines contributed 32% of value added, 
and accounted for 8% of business establishments and 31% of 
employment.  SMEs’  direct  contribution  to  total  manufacturing 
exports was approximately 24%, but the indirect contribution as 
suppliers  to  large  exporters  is  likely  to  be  higher.  SMEs  thus 
comprise a vital subsector in the economy in terms of employment 
and  value  added.  However,  effective  SME  operation  is 
constrained by lack of supportive policies; cumbersome and costly

ii     
registration and licensing processes; lack of a national business 
registry and collateral registry; and lack of comprehensive credit 
information, which hampers SME lending.  
 
Access  to  and  availability  of  finance,  another  key  constraint, 
reflects (i) banks’ reluctance to expand SME lending following the 
Asian financial crisis (SME lending is perceived to be costly and 
risky  in  relation  to  revenues  generated  compared  with  other 
investments) and lack of credible credit information; and (ii) SMEs’ 
difficulty preparing and presenting credible business plans and 
realistic cash-flow estimates, and providing sufficient collateral for 
bank lending. The Government and development community have 
responded  by  supporting  the  development  of  business 
development services (BDS) to help SMEs with business plans, 
financial management, marketing, and accounting. In 1991 the 
Government  set  up  SB  Corporation  to  provide  loans  and 
guarantees to SMEs, in particular those that are viable and either 
need loans below banks’ minimum limit or cannot meet banks’ 
stringent collateral requirements.  
 
In July 2004, the Government presented the SME Development 
Plan 2004–2010 to improve the enabling environment for SMEs 
and thereby contribute to increased SME share in value added—
from 32% to 40% by 2010. President Arroyo’s 10-point agenda 
and  the  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  (MTPDP) 
2004–2010 also highlight SME support as central to creating at 
least  6  million  jobs  by  2010.  The  MTPDP  includes  the 
establishment of a credit bureau as one of the targeted activities 
to promote SME development. 
 
The SME Development Plan includes a number of activities to 
improve the enabling environment for SMEs, i.e., from registration 
and licensing to micro issues of providing BDS throughout the 
country, assisting SMEs with matching, market access information 
and even product design. The plan does not address the overall 
policy and regulatory framework affecting enterprises, large and 
small,  such  as  financial  sector  issues,  taxation,  competition 
framework, corporate recovery and insolvency law, and need for 
more developed infrastructure.  
   
  Impact and Outcome  The SMEDSP is to help the Government implement the SME 
Development  Plan,  in  cooperation  with  other  development 
partners,  to  promote  SME  development  and  broad-based 
economic growth. In President Arroyo’s 10-point agenda and the 
MTPDP, the concrete target is to create at least 6 million jobs in 6 
years by promoting SMEs, tripling financing available, supporting 
entrepreneurs, and developing land for agricultural business. The 
SMEDSP and associated projects will support this objective by (i) 
improving  the  enabling  environment  for  SMEs,  (ii)  stimulating 
SME  development  by  facilitating  access  to  finance  and 
augmenting  financial  resources  at  SB  Corporation,  and  (iii)

iii
expanding  private  sector  lending  for  medium-size  enterprises 
supported by a PCG. This combination of a public sector loan and 
private sector PCG allows for targeting of different segments of 
the SME market and catalyzing expanded SME finance through a 
demonstration effect. The SMEDSP will effectively complement 
efforts  by  other  development  partners  that  concentrate  on 
providing BDS to SMEs nationwide, as well as efforts to support 
policymaking  by  the  Department  of  Trade  and  Industry.  The 
associated  projects  will  support  targeted  SME  issues;  macro 
policies are beyond the scope of this Project.  
   
  Cost Estimates   The total cost is estimated at $38.5 million equivalent.

Project Benefits and  The SMEDSP, associated TA, and JFICT project are expected to 
Beneficiaries  contribute  to  an  improved  enabling  environment  for  SMEs,  a

Risks and Assumptions  One  of  the  main  factors  affecting  SMEDSP  is  overall  the 
macroeconomic  environment.  Current  projections  for  the 
Philippines indicate an average 4.9% annual real gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  growth  for  2005–2009,  with  inflation  on  a 
downward trend to about 4% and the budget deficit being reduced 
to about 1% of GDP by 2009. Adverse developments in the world 
economy  could  dampen  growth  prospects  in  the  Philippines. 
Conversely, stronger than projected growth in the world economy 
could lead to higher growth.  
 
The main assumptions for the SMEDSP also carry some risks that 
are addressed by mitigating measures. The assumptions are (i) 
the Government is strongly committed and has the capacity to 
implement the SMEDSP as an integral part of a comprehensive 
support program for SME development; (ii) SB Corporation has 
sufficient capacity to absorb the ADB loan; (iii) SB Corporation’s 
credit expansion has no potential adverse impact on private sector 
banks;  and  (iv)  private  sector  banks  have  the  capacity  to 
effectively utilize the resources, including the PCG.  
   
The  Government  is  strongly  committed  to  supporting  SME 
development by implementing the SME Development Plan 2004–
2010, and President Arroyo’s 10-point agenda as expanded in the 
MTPDP.  The  MTPDP  also  emphasizes  the  need  to  increase

vii
investment and trade, and recognizes that the high cost of doing 
business must be reduced, and infrastructure must be modernized 
if growth and employment targets are to be realized. An action 
program to prioritize and implement the SME Development Plan is 
developed  to  ensure  appropriate  sequencing  of  activities  and 
securing  budgetary  allocations  and/or  development  funding  for 
activities. The SME Donor Working Group is an active forum for 
collaboration to ensure that efforts are complementary. 
 
SB Corporation is expected to be able to channel funds effectively 
through accredited PFIs as these are experienced SME lenders 
with a broad network of branches. The selection criteria used 
under  the  accreditation  system  of  SB  Corporation  are  quite 
conservative  and  correspond  to  ADB  Guidelines  on  Financial 
Intermediary  Loans  for  selecting  PFIs.  SB  Corporation  has 
developed  a  model  for  retail  lending,  and  has  a  proven  track 
record  of  SME  financing  operations  and  a  strong  pipeline  of 
projects for both retail and wholesale funding. The associated TA 
will  strengthen  SB  Corporation’s  credit  underwriting  and  risk 
management.  Upon  enactment  of  amendments  to  the  SME 
Magna Carta, Republic Act 6977, SB Corporation will have (i) 
discretion in its staffing and remuneration policies, (ii) a sovereign 
guarantee reinstated, and (iii) greater discretion over funding and 
investment decisions.  
 
No adverse effect on commercial bank lending is expected to 
result from SB Corporation’s loan expansion as the target groups 
are  not  adequately  served  by  commercial  banks.  With  the 
establishment of the CIB, the commercial banks will gain access 
to comprehensive credit information on SME borrowers, enabling 
them to make more informed credit decisions. 
 
To ensure effective utilization of the PCG, allocation will be based 
on demand projected by the selected banks. ADB will bear the 
operational risk of the PFIs in terms of their credit assessment and 
due diligence in identifying credit-worthy SMEs. These risks are 
mitigated by the (i) negotiated first-loss provision, (ii) loss-sharing 
structure of the SMEDSP where the PFI will cover a 50% share of 
credit loss, (iii) annual review of the PFI’s credit program where 
ADB reserves the right to cancel the unused limit, and (iv) the PFI 
accounting for a credit risk equivalent to the full extent of the 
unguaranteed portion (i.e., no third party insurance, guarantees, 
or government subsidy) to increase PFIs commitment to the credit 
program.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
loan  to  the  Small  Business  Guarantee  and  Finance  Corporation  (SB  Corporation)  to  be 
guaranteed by the Republic of the Philippines; (ii) a proposed partial credit guarantee (PCG) to 
selected private sector financial institutions without a Government counterguarantee; and (iii) a 
proposed equity investment in the planned credit information bureau (CIB) for the Small and 
Medium Enterprise Development Support Project (SMEDSP).  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
2.  The  SMEDSP  was  developed  in  response  to  a  Government  request  for  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) assistance in implementing the Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) 
Development Plan 2004–2010. The Government views SME development as central to poverty 
reduction efforts through generation of employment opportunities and development of a sound 
and broad-based private sector. An ADB project preparatory technical assistance (TA) analyzed 
the Government’s SME development policies and actions to date, issues and constraints facing 
SMEs, and the operational and financial status of SB Corporation.1 The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
3.  In 2002, SMEs in the Philippines contributed 32% of value added, and accounted for 8% 
of business establishments and 31% of employment. Shares of value added and sales by SMEs 
follow an increasing trend, from 30% and 31% respectively in 1998, compared with 21% and 
22% in 1983, and 28% and 28% in 1993. The SMEs’ direct contribution to total manufacturing 
exports was approximately 24%, but the indirect contribution as suppliers to large exporters is 
likely to be higher. SME are thus a vital subsector in the economy.  
 
4.  Small  enterprises  are  defined  as  those  with  asset  size  between  P3,000,000  and 
P15,000,000, while medium enterprises have assets between P15,000,000 and P100,000,000. 
By definition based on number of employees, a small enterprise is one that employs 10–99 
people, while a medium enterprise employs 100–199.2 In 2001, the total 825,000 registered 
business establishments included 61,759 registered small and 2,923 medium enterprises; the 
vast majority were microenterprises. SMEs are found in practically all subsectors. However, 
most (more than 78%) are concentrated within a fairly traditional range of product groups: food 
processing; garments; gifts, toys, and handicrafts; metal working; footwear and leather goods; 
wood and bamboo products; and building materials. In terms of geographic distribution, the 
National Capital Region accounts for 24.4% of all SME establishments and 40% of employees.  
 
5.  The importance of SMEs to the Philippine economy is reflected in the SME Magna 
Carta, or Republic Act 6977 enacted in 1991.3 The act summarizes the SME policy goals: to 
raise productivity, ensure access to modern technology and financing, and lower the costs of 
doing business. The act also launched three major initiatives: (i) created the SME Development 
Council  as  the  primary  body  for  developing  the  SME  sector  through  policy  formulation, 
interdepartmental coordination, and promotion of SME development programs; (ii) specified 
mandatory credit allocations by all banks to SMEs: 6% of lending to small enterprises and 2% to

6.   In July 2004, President Arroyo announced a 10-point agenda of reforms for her 6-year 
term. The first item is creation of at least 6 million jobs in 6 years through support for SME 
development by tripling credit available to SMEs, developing land for agricultural business, and

2010  includes  targets  for  SME  lending  and  provides  strategies  for  government  financial

agencies to implement the MTPDP and submit quarterly scorecards to monitor progress. The 
Government also presented the SME Development Plan 2004–2010, a comprehensive sector 
development plan to be implemented by concerned Government agencies in partnership with 
the private sector and development partners. The plan identifies eight strategies, each with 
specific activities. The SME plan is the result of numerous inputs from DTI, Small and Medium 
Enterprise  Development  Council,  and  industry  associations  in  the  Philippines,  as  well  as 
development  assistance-funded  studies  and  TA. 4  With  implementation  of  the  plan,  the 
Government projects SME gross value added will increase to 40% of the total, and SME exports 
will grow at 16% annually based on the gross domestic product (GDP) growth targets for 2004–
2010 developed by the National Economic Development Authority.  
 
7.  The SME Development Plan identifies activities to improve the enabling environment for 
SMEs, such as improving registration and licensing processes, providing business development 
services (BDS) throughout the country, assisting SMEs with matching, and developing market 
access information and even product design. The plan does not address the overall policy and 
regulatory framework affecting SMEs, such as financial sector issues, taxation, competition 
framework, corporate recovery and insolvency law, labor market policies, and need for more 
infrastructure development. Instead the plan focuses on tangible issues that will have a direct 
impact on SME operations. An action program for implementing the SME Development Plan in 
a sequenced and coordinated manner has been developed and was presented during SME 
week in July 2005. Lead agencies and key people responsible for each activity have been 
identified. The key people are tasked with bringing stakeholders together for each activity and 
determining  actions  needed,  sequencing  the  actions,  and  determining  resources  for 
implementation. DTI has provided a general prioritization of activities based on sequencing and 
fund availability. The action program will have time-bound targets for the initiatives. Appendix 2 
provides a matrix of activities in the SME Development Plan, including designated lead agency 
by activity and how development partners’ ongoing or planned activities match. The plan does 
not capture all SME-related activities and projects supported by the development partners.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  The Policy and Enabling Environment 
12.  A conducive policy environment is vital for SMEs to flourish, and contribute to economic 
growth and employment. That generally means clear, predictable, and simple rules regarding 
licensing, registration, taxation, and collateral registration so that SMEs can start operations and 
access  finance.  While the  SME  Magna  Carta  formed  the  framework  for  the  overall  policy 
direction, SMEs still face a policy environment that is not adequately supportive. Major policy 
issues to improve the investment climate, such as revisions to the incentive system, competition 
policies expanded to more sectors, and changes to the tax system are examined in the ADB 
reports  Improving  the  Investment  Climate  in  the  Philippines  and  the  draft  Private  Sector 
Assessment for the Philippines. The ADB Southeast Asia Regional Department is analyzing 
options  to  address  some  of  these  measures  under  a  broader  private  sector  development 
initiative. However, significant targeted policy measures also have a direct effect on the SME 
enabling environment.  
 
13.  A  number  of  surveys  have  revealed  that  SMEs  perceive  registration  and  licensing 
procedures to be cumbersome and costly with the process taking an average of 59 days and 
requiring 11 procedures. Furthermore, they cite collateral problems as hindering access to 
finance.8 Growth and export-oriented SMEs identify insufficient market knowledge and market 
access as issues. The framework for registration and licensing is indeed complicated. Single 
proprietorships register with DTI, while partnerships and corporations register with the Securities 
and Exchange Commission (SEC). In addition, every enterprise needs to get a license from the 
local government unit (LGU); this must be renewed annually. Registration with DTI and SEC 
serve as name registration, while the LGU license in effect allows the company to become 
operational  as  the  license  indicates  that  the  company  satisfies  all  national  and  LGU 
requirements to operate in its respective field. The LGUs thus have the most reliable data on 
active  companies.  In  addition,  the  National  Internal  Revenue  Code  requires  all  business 
establishments to register with the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) to comply with the firm’s 
obligation to pay national income taxes, and act as a Government withholding tax agent. The 
SME Development Council has found that many SMEs register with DTI solely to register the 
business name, long before they start operations, which some never do. The SME Development 
Plan (Activity 48) calls for streamlining and facilitating registration and licensing processes.  
 
14.  Because of the variety of registering agencies and the separate licensing process, no 
single  comprehensive  national  business  registry  serves  as  (i)  name  registration  for  the 
company,  (ii)  BIR  registry,  (iii)  repository  of  LGU  licensed  enterprises,  (iv)  registry  where 
financial  institutions  can  verify  loan  applications  from  companies,  (v)  data  source  for  the 
National Statistics Office, and (vi) database for DTI policymaking. To address this, the SME 
Development Plan recommends development of the Philippine business registry (PBR) as one 
activity.  Now  designed,  the  registry  is  ready  to  be  established.  Implementation  will  be 
undertaken in phases, starting with the agencies involved, i.e., BIR, DTI, SEC, and major LGUs 
that have electronic systems and can interface with the other agencies. Over time, the registry 
will be linked to other government agencies such as Department of Labor and Employment, 
National  Statistics  Office,  and  Social  Security  System.  The  PBR  is  envisaged  to  provide 
electronic registration and submission of licensing requests, which would simplify processes, 
lower costs, and enhance governance. Thus the basic requirements for SME registration and

15.  DTI has established SME centers around the country; 10 are fully operational. They

the DTI SME centers could be one-stop shops for SME registration and licensing. For a fee, the 
centers could process papers and ensure the company is duly registered in the national system. 
 
2.  Access to and Availability of Finance  
 
16.  In focus group discussions for the recent national survey on SMEs by the Employers 
Confederation of the Philippines and the International Labour Organization as well as a survey 
under the project preparatory TA, business owners and BDS providers described access to 
financing  as  the  most  pressing  constraint  facing  SMEs.  Access  to  commercial  banks  is 
particularly limited for small firms, which are able to source only 5–7% of their financing needs 
from banks. Most SME entrepreneurs rely on family, friends, business partners, and informal 
financing sources. In a survey of SMEs that have not accessed bank financing, inability to meet 
collateral requirements was the top constraint. While 92% of the 62 banks surveyed under the 
project preparatory TA offered short-term working capital facilities to SMEs, only 53% offered 
fixed asset financing instruments. Access to trade and supplier financing is also limited.9 
 
17.  Banks perceive SMEs as riskier than larger firms due to their low capital base, limited 
product lines leading to greater vulnerability to business cycle fluctuations, and vulnerability to 
deterioration in receivables collections or loss of a key officer, among others. SMEs are also 
perceived to have weak financial discipline, with business funds often mixed with the owners’ 
personal funds; and generally to have weak accounting systems. SMEs rarely use banks to 
manage their payroll or for working accounts, and the bank-client relationship tends to be 
weaker than for medium to large companies. For the banks, each SME transaction is therefore 
costly, as it generally requires more staff resources in relation to the revenue that the loan 
generates compared with lending to larger firms with which the bank has a solid bank-client 
relationship. One remedy has been for banks to only accept titled real estate as collateral, 
generally value it at 60% of appraised value, and set the loan floor at P1 million ($17,860), thus 
concentrating their SME lending to a certain market segment.  
 
18.  Seventy  percent  of  SME  lending  is  collateral  based,  but  many  SMEs  either  have 
insufficient collateral or cannot have it properly registered because of the lack of a movable 
collateral  registry.  Banks  must  undertake  their  own  assessments  of  the  ownership  of  the 
movable collateral, which makes the process longer and more costly. The lack of a movable

19.  The  Philippines  does  not  have  a  comprehensive  credit  bureau  because  of  legal 
impediments to reporting credit information. This has led to inaccurate credit assessments and 
higher risk for lenders. Meanwhile, borrowers face long credit application processes, higher

information. The CISA will have a central credit bureau at its core (due to be established by the 
end of 2005) and will govern the interplay of information between providers and subscribers. 
BSP will play a critical role as the largest shareholder and supervisor. BSP involvement will 
provide the necessary credibility as well as ensure comprehensive collection of banking data.  
 
20.  SMEs have difficulty preparing audited financial statements, and business plans with 
sales and revenue projections that meet bank requirements. Because of difficulty accessing 
formal finance, new SMEs tend to rely on their own or relatives’ funds, and expensive informal 
finance.  DTI  recognizes  this  and  offers  counseling  and  some  assistance  through  its  SME 
centers; a number of development agencies are providing BDS to SMEs throughout the country. 
The  BDS  include  preparation  of  business  plans,  financial  management,  marketing,  and 
accounting, which in turn will ensure that SMEs can present proper business plans to banks on 
which to base a cash-flow analysis that can substitute for or complement collateral for lending. 
In addition to the SME centers, in 2002 DTI introduced SME caravans to extend the reach to the 
provinces. Each caravan, with 4–5 experts in areas such as marketing, trade, finance, and 
technology, provides advisory services and conducts business clinics. In 2002, five caravans 
visited five provinces; in 2003, 36 caravans visited 29 provinces. In most cases, SMEs are not 
charged for these DTI services. Usually, only the administrative costs incurred for organizing 
seminars/workshops  under  the  SME  caravans  are  borne  by  the  participants.  For  further 
consultation, however, SMEs pay full service fees to BDS providers. According to a 2003 
survey, conducted jointly by the Employers Confederation of the Philippines and International 
Labour Organization, of 1,000 SMEs nationwide, 80% of those who utilized the DTI services 
found them effective.  
 
21.  SB Corporation is mandated to be the national leader in small enterprise finance, not in 
volume but in innovative products and outreach, thereby achieving a demonstration effect. SB 
Corporation targets underserved SMEs that are viable but cannot access bank finance and 
typically need smaller loans than most banks normally offer. Under the wholesale lending 
program or rediscounting facility, SB Corporation accredits financial institutions nationwide and 
then provides credit for SME lending through these accredited banks, thereby providing SMEs 
wider access to short- and medium-term financing. The SB Corporation funding provides the 
accredited banks with a wider array of SME loan products to offer their clients. A key advantage 
of SB Corporation products is that the pass-on rate from SB Corporation is fixed and the conduit 
bank can therefore offer fixed terms to their clients as opposed to revising interest rates each 
month. Another advantage is the longer term products that SB Corporation offers with terms up 
to 7 years. Since 1994, SB Corporation disbursed (as of December 2003) P8.53 billion ($152 
million) benefiting 5,158 SMEs.  
 
22.  SB  Corporation  started  retail  lending  operations  in  1999  when  the  private  financial 
institutions slowed their lending to SMEs. Direct loans disbursed to 1,207 SMEs from 1999 to 
December 2003 aggregated P1.4 billion ($25 million). Retail lending is coursed through SB 
Corporation’s five offices, where account officers review the applications and make an initial 
assessment of whether the applicant meets the basic borrowing requirements, and if so and a

7 
site visit is favorable, then the application is sent to the credit committee at head office in Manila 
for approval. The SMEs targeted in the direct lending are those that are viable, but need small 
loans, have a short track record and insufficient collateral to meet banks’ normal requirements. 
The development aspect of SB Corporation is to support these viable SMEs with a view to move 
them to bank financing after 3–5 years. SB Corporation also has a guarantee program offering 
participating  banks  guarantees  on  their  SME  loans,  thereby  allowing  expansion  of  SME 
portfolios. Total guarantees issued amount to P8.66 billion for 4,675 accounts. Even though SB 
Corporation is a GFI it does not have a sovereign guarantee, and this in combination with a 
processing cycle that is perceived by participating banks as long and cumbersome are cited as 
the main reasons for banks limited interest in applying for SB Corporation’s guarantee program. 
Details about SB Corporation are in Appendix 3.  
 
23.  Recognizing  the  comparatively  low  levels  of  SME  lending  and  the  cumbersome 
procedures surrounding it, the Government launched the SME Unified Lending Opportunities for 
National Growth (SULONG) program in 2003. The aim was to facilitate SME financing by 
simplifying and standardizing GFI lending procedures, including those of SB Corporation, to 
make loan processing swifter. SME centers and DTI provincial offices disseminate information 
to help SMEs tap the SULONG program. Small business counselors and technical staff facilitate 
SME access the SULONG program by helping them fill out loan application forms, generating 
documents required, and following up on the status of loan processing with SB Corporation. 
Initially interest rates were fixed for different types of maturity loans making the SULONG a 
suboptimal  lending  product  for  the  GFIs.  Therefore  the  SULONG  committee  requested  in 
September 2004 that the cap be lifted allowing the GFIs to differentiate market-based rates 
according to the client and type of loan. In October 2004 a decision was made to move to 
formula-based interest rates reflecting funding costs and credit risks.  
 
24.  During  preliminary  discussions  of  the  ADB  Private  Sector  Operations  Department 
(PSOD) with six local and international commercial banks, the banks expressed interest in 
expanding their SME lending portfolios beyond the legally mandated 8%. The renewed interest 
of domestic banks in the SME market results from increased competition and tight margins in 
the large borrower segment, as well as BSP regulatory incentives to encourage lending to 
SMEs. However, domestic banks cite capital constraints and insufficient SME collateral as the 
main constraints to profitable expansion of their SME portfolio. An increased level of lending to 
SMEs  would  require  increased  capital,  but  problems  with  nonperforming  assets  limit  their 
options. BSP encourages banks to remove nonperforming assets to free up resources for 
lending and strengthen the banking system at large. Removing these assets, however, by sale 
to an asset management company is normally done at significantly discounted face value. This 
means that banks have to realize losses that in turn require more capital to meet the capital 
adequacy ratio requirement. Hence, banks that cannot raise sufficient capital may opt to reduce 
SME  lending  and  continue  to  invest  in  less  risky  assets,  and  only  slowly  deal  with  the 
nonperforming assets.  
 
25.  Local and international commercial banks tend to rely on collateral for SME lending, and 
typically only titled real estate. Some SMEs lack this, and even though their revenues may be 
substantial (such as medium-size call centers) they have difficulty accessing finance based on 
cash flow alone. International banks would also like to diversify their loan portfolios to improve 
their  risk  profile  and  broaden  their  sources  of  revenue.  They  are  therefore  interested  in 
expanding to the SME market. Among the options they are considering is a channel financing 
structure  that  puts  more  emphasis  on  cash  flow  than  collateral.  This  structure  identifies 
multinational company clients of the bank and the dealers with payables to the multinational 
company. The international bank will lend the dealer an amount equal to the amount in the

8     
multinational company’s invoice. The dealer then sells to the final consumer and upon payment 
repays the international bank. This type of structure can be expanded to the SME market 
provided the bank can share the risk.

4.  Lessons Learned 
 
27.  ADB  draft  guidelines  for  SME  projects,  developed  in  2004,  draw  upon  previous 
experience with SME projects. The main recommendations include the following: 
 
  (i)  ADB  public  and  private  sector  operations  need  to  work  more  closely  to 
complement each other. 
  (ii)  Public  sector  operations  should  primarily  focus  on  creating  an  enabling 
environment  including  regulatory,  business  registration,  governance,  stronger 
financial  sector,  and  building  of  appropriate  institutions  and  capacity  of  the 
financial sector. 
  (iii)  Future SME operations should use a cluster approach or interlinked projects. A 
project should not try to address all possible issues. Rather, it should be viewed 
as  a  building  block  to  develop  a  business  environment  conducive  for  SME 
development. 
(iv)  SME operations must be closely coordinated with other external aid agencies 
and, where possible, activities linked with other aid agency support in the sector.  
 
28.  In 1996, the World Bank undertook a detailed empirical analysis of its SME support over 
20 years in three countries (Ecuador, Philippines, and Sri Lanka).10 The study concluded that 
credit lines for term financing need to be designed carefully to achieve expected outcomes. Key 
lessons  include  the  need  to  ensure  realistic  expectations  and  projections  of  job  creation, 
develop SME credit underwriting skills, and focus on improving the policy environment to ensure 
access to financing.  
 
29.  The  SMEDSP  and  associated  projects  are  designed  to  take  lessons  learned  into 
consideration given that they are joint public-private sector operations. The SMEDSP includes a

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
31.  The overall goal of the SMEDSP and associated projects is to help the Government 
implement  its  SME  Development  Plan  2004–2010  in  cooperation  with  other  development 
partners, and by supporting SME development to contribute to broad-based economic growth to 
generate employment opportunities. In President Arroyo’s 10-point agenda and the MTPDP, the 
concrete target is to create at least 6 million jobs in 6 years through, among other things, 
promoting SMEs by tripling financing available, supporting entrepreneurs, and developing land 
for agricultural business. The SMEDSP and associated projects supports this objective by 
improving the enabling environment for SMEs; stimulating SME development by facilitating 
access to finance and augmenting financial resources at SB Corporation; and expanding private 
sector lending for medium enterprises supported by a PCG. This combination of a public sector 
loan and private sector PCG allows for targeting of different segments of the SME market and 
catalyzing expanded SME finance through a demonstration effect. The associated TA13 will 
enhance SB Corporation’s capacity and performance in supporting SME development. The 
SMEDSP  will  effectively  complement  efforts  by  other  development  partners  that  mostly 
concentrate on providing BDS to SMEs nationwide, as well as efforts to support policymaking by 
DTI.

46.   First, the SMEDSP is a combination of public and private sector modalities to ensure 
that different segments of SMEs are reached. The smaller and newer SMEs will be targeted 
through the credit line to SB Corporation. Larger SMEs that have limited access to bank finance 
will be targeted under the PCG. The two financing facilities effectively complement each other.

47.   Second,  the  credit  line  will  be  released  in  phases  with  a  holistic  approach  to  SB 
Corporation’s operations aimed at improving financial performance and expanding lending in

program will be supported, and during the second phase, retail lending will be supported as

complementary role to the private sector by focusing on an underserved and important group of 
SMEs. Because of this, the ADB credit line is expected to (i) demonstrate that SME lending 
based on alternative collateral and cash flows is profitable, (ii) contribute to sustainable SME 
financing in the targeted market, and (iii) expand the future client base of private sector banks

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impact  
 
69.  The  SMEDSP,  associated  TA,  and  JFICT  project  are  expected  to  contribute  to  an 
improved enabling environment for SMEs, a financially stronger SB Corporation better equipped 
to  expand  its  portfolio  at  the  wholesale  and  retail  level,  expanded  SME  lending  by  SB 
Corporation and commercial banks, improved access to credit information by banks and other 
credit providers, and increased SME growth and job creation by SMEs. SMEs are expected to 
benefit from better access to and augmented availability of finance. The project preparatory TA 
report provided estimates based on previous lending. During 1994–1997 under the wholesale 
lending window P1 million lent generated 3.18 additional jobs, and under the retail window 
1999–2003 P1 million lent generated 6.74 additional jobs. Using that as a guide, a static 
calculation indicates at least 3,500 and 1,800 additional jobs under the two lending windows 
respectively. However, any estimates can only give indicative figures given the variety of SMEs 
in terms of labor intensity. Successful project implementation will result in increased SME 
investments, output, exports, and employment; but exact targets for each variable are not 
realistic.  The  SMEDSP  will  be  effectively  complemented  by  other  development  programs 
targeted  at  BDS  (GTZ  and  Canadian  International  Development  Agency),  microenterprises 
(United States Agency for International Development), SMEs in the Visayas region (KfW), and 
possible further assistance by other development partners. A summary of poverty reduction and 
social strategy considerations is given in Appendix 11.  
 
B.  Risks and Assumptions  
 
70.  One of the main factors affecting SMEDSP is overall the macroeconomic environment. 
Current projections for the Philippines indicate an average 4.9% annual real gross domestic 
product (GDP) growth for 2005–2009, with inflation on a downward trend to about 4% and the 
budget deficit being reduced to about 1% of GDP by 2009. Adverse developments in the world 
economy could dampen growth prospects in the Philippines; conversely, higher than projected 
growth in the world economy could lead to higher growth.

19 
 
71.  The main assumptions for the SMEDSP also carry some risks that are addressed by 
mitigating measures. The assumptions are (i) the Government is strongly committed and has 
the capacity to implement the SMEDSP as an integral part of a comprehensive support program 
for SME development; (ii) SB Corporation has sufficient capacity to absorb the ADB loan; (iii) 
credit expansion of SB Corporation will not have any potential adverse impact on private sector 
banks; and (iv) private banks have the capacity to effectively utilize the resources, including the 
PCG.  
 
72.  The Government is strongly committed to supporting SME development by implementing 
the SME Development Plan 2004–2010, and President Arroyo’s 10-point agenda as expanded 
in the MTPDP 2004–2010. The MTPDP emphasizes the need to increase investments and 
trade, and recognizes that the high cost of doing business must be reduced, and infrastructure 
modernized to realize growth and employment targets. The action program to prioritize and 
implement  the  SME  Development  Plan  will  ensure  appropriate  sequencing  and  securing 
budgetary allocations or aid funding for activities. The SME Donor Working Group is an active 
forum for collaboration to ensure that efforts are complementary. 
 
73.  SB Corporation is expected to be able to channel funds effectively through accredited 
PFIs as these are experienced SME lenders with a broad network of branches. The selection 
criteria used under the accreditation system of SB Corporation are quite conservative and can 
correspond  to  ADB  Guidelines  on  Financial  Intermediary  Loans  for  selecting  PFIs.  SB 
Corporation  has  developed  a  model  for  retail  lending,  has  a  proven  track  record  of  SME 
financing  operations,  and  a  strong  pipeline  of  projects  for  both  retail  and  wholesale.  The 
associated TA will strengthen SB Corporation’s credit underwriting and risk management. Upon 
enactment of amendments to the SME Magna Carta, Republic Act 6977, SB Corporation will 
have (i) discretion in its staffing and remuneration policies, (ii) a sovereign guarantee reinstated, 
and (iii) greater discretion over funding and investment decisions.  
 
74.  As a GFI, SB Corporation abides by Executive Order 138, which limits GFIs to providing 
wholesale funds to private financial institutions engaged in retail lending. The order only allows 
GFIs to provide retail services to the target sectors not adequately served by private financial 
institutions. Thus retail lending operations of SB Corporation are mandated to support SMEs 
underserved  by  the  private  sector  financial  institutions.  Expanding  SB  Corporation  lending 
operations has  no  potential  adverse  impact on  private sector  banks.  On  the contrary,  SB 
Corporation aims to capture the underserved segment of the SME market and has a policy to 
graduate its borrowers to become private sector bank clients. SB Corporation’s capacity will be 
strengthened through TA to ensure that credit expansion is undertaken in a prudent manner. 
 
75.  To ensure effective utilization of the PCG, PCG allocation will be made based on the 
demand projected by the selected banks. ADB will also bear the operational risk on the PFIs in 
terms of their credit assessment and due diligence in identifying reliable SMEs. These risks are 
mitigated by the (i) loss-sharing structure of the project where the PFI will cover 50% share on 
credit loss, (ii) annual review of the PFI’s credit program where ADB reserves the right to cancel 
the unused limit, and (iii) the PFI accounting for a credit risk equivalent to the full extent of the 
unguaranteed portion (i.e. no third party insurance, guarantees, or government subsidy) to 
increase commitment to the credit program.

AN OVIERVIEW OF SMALL BUSINESS GUARANTEE AND FINANCE CORPORATION 
 
A.  Ownership, Management and Organization, and Supervision 
1.  The  Small  Business  Guarantee  and  Finance  Corporation  (SB  Corporation),  a 
government financial institution (GFI), was established on 24 January 1991 under Republic Act 
6977 also known as the Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) Magna Carta, to function as the 
SME financing champion of the national Government. Subscribed and paid-up capital as of 
December  2003  amounted  to  P1.8  billion  contributed  by  five  government  entities  and  the 
Government.1 
 
2.  A nine-member board of directors governs SB Corporation, comprising a representative 
each of the five shareholders, three private sector representatives and the chief executive 
officer who is also the chairs. The chair is responsible for overall operations of SB Corporation, 
assisted by a president and seven group heads. SB Corporation’s head office is in Makati City, 
Metro Manila; it has two regional offices in Cebu and Davao, and two representative offices in 
Luzon. Total number of employees is currently 138. As a GFI, SB Corporation is subject to the 
Salary Standardization Law. 
 
3.  On 16 November 2001, SB Corporation merged with the Guarantee Fund for Small and 
Medium Enterprises, a guarantee fund operated by the Livelihood Corporation attached to the 
Office of the President. It had offered guarantee services to participating financial institutions 
(PFIs)  lending  to  SMEs  since  the  start  of  its  operations  in  1984.  With  the  merger,  the 
Government became the largest shareholder of SB Corporation.2 
 
4.  SB Corporation is supervised by Bangko Sentral Ng Pilipinas (BSP) and adheres to BSP 
regulations on loan classification, provisioning, and single borrower limits even though it is not 
licensed as a bank. As a GFI, SB Corporation is audited annually by the Commission on Audit, 
which publishes the audits on its website, as well as providing print copies.  
 
5.  In March 2004, a new Oracle-based management information system was implemented 
covering  retail  lending,  wholesale  credit  lines,  and  guarantees.  The  standardized  features 
ensure that all necessary data are entered into the database and performance analysis and 
evaluations can be done by line of business or even further refined, such as by subsector, 
geographic region, company asset size, or loan size. Retail lending data for all retail loans since 
2002 has been input to the system to allow effective follow-up and analysis of loan performance 
and defaults. The plan is to put in all data for retail lending since it started in 1999 to form the 
basis for a credit-scoring model. The number of loans is not sufficient for a full-fledged statistical 
model but do support work on a judgmental model and provide data for the associated technical 
assistance (TA) aimed at improving the credit underwriting process. Likewise, the database 
provides SB Corporation’s management and board with detailed data to support decisions on 
the various lending and guarantee programs, as well as facilitates financial management and 
planning.

B.   Operations  
6.  SB Corporation’s operations cover three areas: guarantees, and wholesale and retail 
SME lending. The target market is classified into three groups of SMEs: bankable, nearly 
bankable, and prebankable but viable SMEs. For bankable SMEs, the SB Corporation offers 
wholesale lending facilities to help SMEs obtain funding from the formal financial sector at 
reasonable  interest  rates  with  longer  payment  terms.  For  nearly  bankable  SMEs,  SB 
Corporation offers guarantee facilities allowing SMEs access to credit from the formal financial 
sector by securing a certain percentage of the loan (up to 85%). For prebankable but viable 
SMEs, SB Corporation provides direct loans for short-term receivables, purchase order and/or 
letter of credit financing as well as working capital and fixed asset financing. Features that 
differentiate SB Corporation’s lending from banks is that SB Corporation offers smaller loans, 
with longer repayment terms at fixed interest rates. In terms of collateral, SB Corporation 
accepts a broader range of collateral (e.g., real estate, motor vehicles, receivables, purchasing 
orders, and corporate guarantees) compared with banks that mainly accept titled prime real 
estate lots. Collateral is valued at 64% of principal. This is in order to reach the target group of 
SMEs with smaller financing needs than commercial banks tend to accommodate. 
 
7.  Guarantee operations started in 1992, and by 31 December 2003, SB Corporation had 
guaranteed a total of 4,675 accounts for P8.66 billion. Cumulative guarantee payments from 
1993 to 2002 were at P101.64 million ($1.8 million) with recoveries of P44.86 million ($0.8 
million).  The  payments  represent  4.8%  of  total  guarantees  approved  and  issued  by  SB 
Corporation  for  the  same  period.  The  process  for  guarantees  is  as  follows.  Applications 
received from PFIs are reviewed by the Credit Guarantees Group at SB Corporation. They 
undertake a second due diligence of the application and if complete and favorably evaluated, 
the application is then sent to the Credit Committee for approval. The Credit Guarantees Group 
is seriously understaffed resulting in long processing times, and this, in combination with the fact 
that SB Corporation does not have a sovereign guarantee, are cited by banks as reasons for 
their limited use of SB Corporation’s guarantee.  
 
8.  The  wholesale  lending  window  was  introduced  in  1994.  SB  Corporation’s  board

15.  Historical Performance. Table A6 shows SB Corporation’s financial performance over

required to maintain Government securities equal to its DBP borrowings. This requirement

16.  The loan portfolio at fiscal year (FY) 2004 accounts for approximately 45% of total

years. At this pace the portfolio will double in size by fiscal year-end (FYE) 2007. Over the

Corporation  does  a  small  amount  of  microlending  (on  a  wholesale  basis,  to  microfinance

business. As of FYE2004, shareholders’ equity is estimated to be 67% of total assets. While 
from the point of view of creditors and regulators, this strong capital base is a source of comfort, 
the challenge for management is to leverage the equity base in order to generate returns 
sufficient to create enterprise value. SB Corporation is a profitable operation, and the estimate 
for FYE2004 is 3.3% return on assets.

strong demand for funds from SB Corporation’s PFIs. In addition, SB Corporation is clearly 
committed to maintaining credit quality, which means that loan portfolio quality will not be 
sacrificed in the interests of asset growth. Furthermore, the complementary TA will assist SB

management. In short, the projections are reasonable and achievable, and the organization is

agreed portion (up to 50%) of the SME loan portfolio. The PCGs will have agreed cover 
amounts and time frames to be selected following a due diligence process. The PCGs will detail 
the risk- and reward-sharing arrangements for individual loans within a defined portfolio of loans 
extended by the PFIs to SMEs. The loan portfolio covered under each PCG may be revolving, 
and the portfolio composition may change over time based on lending decisions of the PFI as 
agreed with ADB. ADB will not be involved in the lending decisions of the PFIs, but will agree 
with the PFIs on the lending selection criteria and risk management process. To underscore the

establishments under different authorities, and (ii) a service tool for trade and business development 
facilitation.  
 
The project has three phases: (i) phase I: the various business databases of Department of Trade and 
Industry (DTI) including those of the Board of Investments (BOI) will be upgraded and harmonized with 
the business registration system of the Securities Exchange Commission; (ii) phase II: the integrated 
databases developed under phase 1 will be linked to the Bureau of Internal Revenue, Social Security 
System, Philippine Economic Zone Authority, and selected local government units (LGUs) that are 
prepared for the e-government initiative through a registry system, providing a common interagency 
reference and validation point; a PBR portal will be established; and (iii) phase III, entry points to other 
LGUs and e-ready organizations such as Department of Labor and Employment, Philippine Health 
Insurance Corporation, and one-stop business centers such as small and medium enterprise (SME) 
centers will be increased. A business facilitation system will be developed as an integral complementary 
function of the PBR, and installed in SME centers and LGUs as the delivery channels in this phase.  
 
The  project  will  (i)  improve  governance  by  reducing  discretional  manual  processes  in  business 
registration; (ii) enhance the efficiency of business registration procedures through interfacing DTI system 
with  other  systems;  (iii)  improve  the  policymaking,  monitoring,  and  marketing  functions  of  the 
Government using a knowledge management tool to generate various statistical and analytical reports; 
(iv) promote business opportunities within domestic and international trade through a business facilitation 
platform; and (v) help business enterprises lower their operational costs by streamlining submission of 
information to various Government agencies and others. 
 
PBR  is  in  line  with  the  e-government  Initiatives,  which  will  apply  information  and  communication 
technology to various government projects to enhance the quality and efficiency of government services 
to the public and the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan 2004–2010, which calls for efficient 
government-to-business and government-to-government transactions. Moreover, it supports the 10-point 
agenda of President Arroyo on item 1, 5, and 7, namely job creation, developing digital infrastructure, and 
developing Subic and Clark bases. 
 
The project will help the Government implement phases I and III of the PBR development plan.
